class endemo2.containers.Demand(electricity: float = 0, heat: ~endemo2.containers.Heat = <endemo2.containers.Heat object>, hydrogen: float = 0)[source]

Bases: object

A container for the amount of demand split into different categories. Provides arithmetic operations.

Variables:

  • electricity (float) – Amount of electricity demand.

  • heat (Heat) – Amount of heat demand.

  • hydrogen (float) – Amount of hydrogen demand.

add(other: Demand)[source]

Add the values of “other” demand component-wise to own member variables.

scale(scalar: float)[source]

Scale member variables component-wise with scalar.

class endemo2.containers.Heat(q1: float = 0, q2: float = 0, q3: float = 0, q4: float = 0)[source]

Bases: object

A container for heat split into heat levels. Offers arithmetic operations.

Variables:

  • q1 (float) – Amount for heat level Q1

  • q2 (float) – Amount for heat level Q2

  • q3 (float) – Amount for heat level Q3

  • q4 (float) – Amount for heat level Q4

endemo2.control_parameters module

This module contains the in-model representation of all settings found in Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx

class endemo2.control_parameters.ControlParameters(general_settings: GeneralSettings, industry_settings: IndustrySettings)[source]

Bases: object

The ControlParameter class holds the data given by the Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx file. It is split in general settings, and settings for each sector, indicating non-overlapping parameters for our model.

general_settings: GeneralSettings
industry_settings: IndustrySettings
class endemo2.control_parameters.ForecastMethod(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

The ForecastMethod indicates the preferred way to extrapolate historical data.

Variables:

  • LINEAR – The forecast method utilizing linear regression.

  • QUADRATIC – The forecast method utilizing quadratic regression.

  • EXPONENTIAL – The forecast method utilizing exponential growth.

EXPONENTIAL = 2
LINEAR = 0
QUADRATIC = 1
class endemo2.control_parameters.GeneralSettings(ex_general: DataFrame, ex_country: DataFrame)[source]

Bases: object

The GeneralSettings contain the parameters for the model given in Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx in the GeneralSettings and Countries sheets.

Parameters:

  • ex_general (pd.DataFrame) – The dataframe of the “GeneralSettings”-sheet in Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx

  • ex_country (pd.DataFrame) – The dataframe of the “Countries”-sheet in Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx

Variables:

  • _sectors_active_values (dict[str, bool]) – Contains information, whether a sector is activ, as indicated by the settings.

  • _parameter_values (dict[str, bool]) – Holds the values from the GeneralSettings table in a dictionary {Parameter_string -> bool}

  • target_year (int) – This is the year, the model makes predictions for.

  • recognized_countries ([str]) – This is the list of countries that are in the “Countries”-sheet of Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx

  • active_countries ([str]) – This is the list of active countries. Only for these countries, calculations are performed.

  • nuts2_version (int) – The version of NUTS2 used for reading the files that hold information per NUTS2 Region. Currently, it should be either 2016 or 2021.

get_active_sectors()[source]
Returns:

The list of sectors activated for calculation.

get_parameter(name: str)[source]
Returns:

The parameter value by parameter name with meaningful error message.

class endemo2.control_parameters.IndustrySettings(ex_general: DataFrame, ex_subsectors: DataFrame)[source]

Bases: object

The IndustrySettings contain the parameters for the model given in Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx in the IND_general and IND_subsectors sheets.

Variables:

  • forecast_map (dict[str, ForecastMethod]) – Maps the forecast method string, used in the setting tables, to the internal enum representation.

  • forecast_method (ForecastMethod) – Contains the currently selected forecast method.

  • time_trend_model_activation_quadratic (bool) – “If the time trend model is deactivated, the traditional approach is selected”

  • production_quantity_calc_per_capita (bool) – Decides, whether the production quantity prognosis should use per-capita projection.

  • trend_calc_for_spec (bool) – Decides, whether specific consumption should be predicted from historical data, when available.

  • h2_subst_of_heat (float) – “Values from 0 to 1. For max. possible substitution of heat with hydrogen in industrial processes set 1.”

  • nuts2_distribution_based_on_installed_ind_capacity (bool) – “If false, distribution per population density.”

  • skip_years ([int]) – Years that are skipped while reading files, to remove outliers.

  • last_available_year (int) – Last year that’s read from historical production files (exclusive).

  • product_settings (dict[str, ProductSettings]) – Contains settings for each product. Of the form {product_name -> product_settings_obj}

  • active_product_names ([str]) – A list of the names of active products. Only for these products, calculations are performed.

  • rest_sector_growth_rate (float) –

forecast_map = {'Exponential': ForecastMethod.EXPONENTIAL, 'Trend': ForecastMethod.LINEAR, 'U-shape': ForecastMethod.QUADRATIC}
class endemo2.control_parameters.ProductSettings(active, manual_exp_change_rate, perc_used)

Bases: tuple

Alias for field number 0

manual_exp_change_rate

endemo2.country module

class endemo2.country.Country(name: str, input_manager: Input)[source]

Bases: object

The Country connects all sectors and data from a single country. It is a completely self-contained unit.

Parameters:

  • name – Name of the country.

  • input_manager – The input manager containing all the input files, so country can fill the variables in its constructor.

Variables:

  • _name (str) – The name of the country (en).

  • _abbreviations ([str]) – Possible abbreviations for this country.

  • _population (Population[PredictedTimeseries, NutsRegion]) – Population object, containing important data and timeseries of the countries’ population.

  • _gdp (TimeStepSequence) – The Timeseries for the GDP of this country.

  • _sectors (dict[SectorIdentifier, Sector]) – The sector objects for this country, accessible by the sector identifier.

calculate_total_demand(year: int) → Demand[source]

Sum the demand over all sectors of the country.

Parameters:

year – Target year for which the prediction should be calculated.

Returns:

The demand for a country summed over all sectors.

get_gdp() → TimeStepSequence[source]

Getter for the countries’ GDP Timeseries

Returns:

The GDP Timeseries for this country.

get_name() → str[source]

Getter for the country name.

Returns:

The country name (en).

get_population() → Population[source]

Getter for the population container object.

Returns:

The countries’ population container object.

get_sector(sector_id: SectorIdentifier) → Sector[source]

Getter for the sectors of a country. Accessed by the sectors’ identifier.

Parameters:

sector_id – Identifies Sector by enum value from SectorIdentifier.

Returns:

The countries sector corresponding to the sector id.

endemo2.endemo module

class endemo2.endemo.Endemo[source]

Bases: object

This is the instance of the model. From here we control what the model does on the highest level.

Variables:

  • input_manager (Input) – holds all the input from the Excel sheets for the current run of the program.

  • countries (dict[str, Country]) – holds all the country objects, accessible by the countries english name.

countries: dict[endemo2.country.Country]
input_manager: Input

Writes all the output that is useful for debugging, but not necessary for the results.

endemo2.industry_sector module

class endemo2.industry_sector.Industry(country_name: str, population: Population, country_gdp: TimeStepSequence, input_manager: Input)[source]

Bases: Sector

The Industry class represents the industry sector of one country. It holds all products produced by this industry.

Parameters:

  • country_name (str) – Name of the country this industry is located in.

  • population (Population) – The population object of the country.

  • country_gdp (TimeStepSequence) – The countries’ GDP Timeseries

  • input_manager (Input) – The models input data from the Excel files.

Variables:

_products (dict[str, Product]) – All products in this industry.

calculate_product_demand(product_name: str, year: int) → Demand[source]

Getter for a products demand by product name and for the year. If the product is not in the industry, a Demand object indicating zero demand is returned.

Parameters:

  • product_name – The name of the product, whose demand should be returned.

  • year – Target year the demand should be calculated for.

Returns:

The demand of the product in this industry.

calculate_total_demand(year: int) → Demand[source]

Sums over the demand of each product.

Parameters:

year – Target year the demand should be calculated for.

Returns:

The demand summed over all products in this industry.

get_product(name: str) → Product[source]

Getter for a product from the industry.

Parameters:

name – Name of the product. Example: “steel_prim”.

Returns:

Product object with the matching name.

prog_product_amount(product_name: str, year: int) → float[source]

Getter for the predicted amount of a product within this industry.

Parameters:

  • product_name – Name of the product. Example: “steel_prim”.

  • year – Target year, which the amount should be calculated for.

Returns:

The products predicted amount in target year.

endemo2.input module

class endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper(file_name: str, sheet_name: str, skip_rows: [int], sheet_transform)[source]

Bases: object

A helper class to read products historical data. It provides some fixed transformation operations.

Variables:

  • file_name (str) – The files name, relative to the path variable.

  • sheet_name (str) – The name of the sheet that is to be read from the file.

  • skip_rows ([int]) – These rows(!) will be skipped when reading the dataframe. Done by numerical index.

  • sheet_transform (lambda[pd.Dataframe -> pd.Dataframe]) – A transformation operation on the dataframe

  • df (pd.Dataframe) – The current dataframe.

  • path (Path) – The path to the folder, where the file is. It can to be set after constructing the FileReadingHelper Object.

get() → DataFrame[source]

Getter for the dataframe.

Returns:

The current dataframe, which is filtered depending on previous function calls on this class.

set_path_and_read(path: Path) → None[source]

Sets the path variable and reads the file with name self.file_name in the path folder.

Parameters:

path – The path, where the file lies.

skip_years(skip_years: [int]) → None[source]

Filters the skip years from the current dataframe.

Parameters:

skip_years – The list of years to skip.

class endemo2.input.GeneralInput(ctrl: ControlParameters, path: Path)[source]

Bases: object

General Input contains all input that is read from the “input/general” folder.

Parameters:

  • ctrl (ControlParameters) – The parsed Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx

  • path (Path) – The path to the input/general folder

Variables:

  • abbreviations (dict[str, ("alpha2", "alpha3", "german_name")]) – The abbreviations for each country.

  • population (PopulationData) – All data from the population input.

  • gdp (dict[str, HisProg[[(float, float)], [Interval, float]]]) – The gdp for each country.

  • efficiency (dict[str, ("electricity", "heat")]) – The efficiency for each energy carrier.

  • nuts2_valid_regions (set) – The set of valid nuts2 regions within the selected NUTS2 code.

class endemo2.input.IndustryInput(industry_path: Path, industry_settings: IndustrySettings)[source]

Bases: object

Industry Input denoted input that is read from the “input/industry” folder.

Parameters:

  • industry_path – The path to the industry folder.

  • industry_settings – The parsed sector-specific settings for the industry sector.

Variables:

  • active_products (dict[str, ProductInput]) – Stores the product specific input for all active products.

  • settings (IndustrySettings) – Stores the sector-specific settings for industry.

  • product_data_access (dict[str, Retrieve]) – Specify how data sheets for each product should be accessed

  • sc_historical_data_file_names (dict[str, str]) – The file names of the files used for certain products to read historical information on specific consumption.

  • sc_historical_sheet_names ([str]) – The sheet names for the files used to read historical information on specific consumption for certain products.

product_data_access = {'alu_prim': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'alu_sec': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'ammonia': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'ammonia_classic': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'aromate': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'aromate_classic': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'cement': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'chlorine': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'copper_prim': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'copper_sec': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'ethylene': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'ethylene_classic': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'glass': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'methanol': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'methanol_classic': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'paper': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'propylene': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'propylene_classic': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'steel': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'steel_direct': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'steel_prim': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>, 'steel_sec': <endemo2.input.FileReadingHelper object>}
sc_historical_data_file_names = {'paper': 'nrg_bal_s_paper.xls', 'steel': 'nrg_bal_s_steel.xls'}
sc_historical_sheet_names = ['Feste fossile Brennstoffe', 'Synthetische Gase', 'Erdgas', 'Oel', 'Erneuerbare Energien', 'Abfaelle', 'Elektrizitaet', 'Waerme']
class endemo2.input.Input[source]

Bases: object

The Input class connects all types of input data, that is in the form of excel/csv sheets in the ‘input’ folder.

Variables:

  • super_path (str) – Path of project folder

  • input_path (str) – Path of input files

  • output_path (str) – Path for output files

  • general_path (str) – Path for input files in “general” folder

  • industry_path (str) – Path for input files in “industry” folder

  • ctrl (ControlParameters) – Holds all information received from Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx

  • general_input (GeneralInput) – Holds all information of the input files from the “input/general” folder.

  • industry_input (IndustryInput) – Holds all information of the input files from the “input/industry” folder.

ctrl: ControlParameters
general_input: GeneralInput
general_path = WindowsPath('C:/Users/Chris/Documents/Master_Semester_1/IDP/endemo2/docs/input/general')

class endemo2.input.PopulationData(ctrl: ControlParameters, nuts2_valid_regions: set, abbreviations: dict, df_country_pop_his: DataFrame, df_country_pop_prog: DataFrame, df_nuts2_pop_his: DataFrame, df_nuts2_pop_prog: DataFrame)[source]

Bases: object

Holds all data on population. That includes historical data, prognosis data for each country and nuts2 region.

Parameters:

  • ctrl (ControlParameters) – The parsed Set_and_Control_Parameters.xlsx file.

  • nuts2_valid_regions (set) – The set of nuts2 regions that are recognized. They are used to filter the input data.

  • abbreviations (dict) – The countries abbreviations, used to access nuts2 data.

  • df_country_pop_his (pd.DataFrame) – The sheet containing data of population history per country.

  • df_country_pop_prog (pd.DataFrame) – The sheet containing the manual prognosis of population amount per country.

  • df_nuts2_pop_his (pd.DataFrame) – The sheet containing data of population history per NUTS2 region.

  • df_nuts2_pop_prog (pd.DataFrame) – The sheet containing the prognosis intervals and growth rate for nuts2 regions.

Variables:

  • country_population (dict[str, HisProg]) – Data for the population of whole countries. It is of the form {country_name -> historical: [(float, float)], prognosis: [(float, float)]}

  • nuts2_population (dict[str, [(str, [float, float])]]) – Data for the population of NUTS2 regions. It is of the form {country_name -> (code -> (historical: [(float,float)], prognosis: [interval, growth rate]))}

class endemo2.input.ProductInput(sc, bat, prod, sc_h, sc_h_active, heat_levels, manual_exp_change_rate, perc_used)[source]

Bases: object

The Product Input summarizes all input data, that is specific to a certain product type, but holds the information for all countries. Example product type: steel_prim

Parameters:

  • sc – specific_consumption_default

  • bat – bat

  • prod – production

  • sc_h – specific_consumption_historical

  • sc_h_active – Indicates whether specific consumption should be calculated from historical data.

  • heat_levels – heat_levels

  • manual_exp_change_rate – manual_exp_change_rate

  • perc_used – perc_used

Variables:

  • specific_consumption_default (dict[str, containers.SC]) – Default specific consumption value for this product.

  • specific_consumption_historical (dict[str, (float, float)]) – Historical specific consumption data for this product. Accessible per country.

  • bat (dict[str, containers.EH]) – The best-available-technology consumption for this product. Accessible per country.

  • production (dict[str, (float, float)]) – The historical amount data for this product. Accessible per country.

  • heat_levels (Heat) – How heat demand should be distributed across heat levels for this product.

  • manual_exp_change_rate (float) – If product amount projection will be calculated exponentially, this will be the change rate.

  • perc_used (float) – A scalar for the amount of a product. This is used to model modern technologies replacing old ones.

endemo2.output module

class endemo2.output.FileGenerator(input_manager, filename)[source]

Bases: object

A tool to more easily generate output files.

Variables:

  • input_manager (Input) – A reference to the input_manager that holds all input.

  • excel_writer (pd.ExcelWriter) – The excel writer used for writing the file.

  • current_sheet_name (str) – Keeps track of the current sheet name that new entries (add_entry) will be written to.

  • current_out_dict (dict) – Keeps the entries that are added. When writing the file, these are converted to a table.

endemo2.population module

class endemo2.population.NutsRegion(region_name, historical_data: [float, float] = None, prediction_data: pm.Interval, float = None)[source]

Bases: object

Represents one NUTS2 Region according to individual codes. It is build as a tree structure to include sub-regions as child nodes.

add_child_region(nuts2region_obj)[source]

Traverses the NUTS Tree recursively to insert region node.

get_historical_data() → [float, float][source]

Get historical data or sum over subregions if not available

get_nodes_dfs() → [NutsRegion][source]

Get a list of all nodes in Depth-First-Search order.

get_pop_prog(year: int) → float[source]

Recursively calculate and sum up the prognosis for all leaf regions

endemo2.utility module

endemo2.utility.combine_data_on_x(x: list[float, float], y: list[float, float], ascending_x=False) → [float, float, float, float][source]

Zip the two lists of tuples on the condition that the first tuple entry matches.

Parameters:

  • x – List to zip nr1 [(a,b)]

  • y – List to zip nr2 [(c, d)]

  • ascending_x – Indicates that the first tuple entry is ascending in the lists. If true, a more efficient algorithm can be used

Returns:

The zipped list in format [(b, d)] for where a == c

endemo2.utility.convert_table_to_filtered_data_series_per_country(df: DataFrame) → dict[source]

Create a dictionary from a table. A key is the first value in row. The corresponding value is a list [column_name, column_value] for the whole row.

Parameters:

df – The dataframe to process

Returns:

The row-oriented dictionary { first_row_entry -> [column_name, column_value]}

endemo2.utility.cut_after_x(data: [float, float], last_x: float) → [float, float][source]

Cuts the tail of a list, according to last

Parameters:

  • data – The data list, whose tail will be cut off.

  • last_x – The x-axis value indicating where to cut the list. (inclusive)

Returns:

The cut data list.

Parameters:

Returns:

True if it can be converted to float, else False.

endemo2.utility.str_dict(dict)[source]
endemo2.utility.zip_on_x(a: list[float, float], b: list[float, float])[source]

A helper function for combine_data_on_x. This is a generator, that returns one value after another. Can be cast to list to apply on whole input at once and create a list as output of form [(a, b), (a, d)]

Parameters:

  • a – List 1 [(a, b)]

  • b – List 2 [(c, d)]

Returns:

Next zipped entry in format ((a, b), (a, d)) for where a == c
